description: From Latin palliatus (“cloaked”) (in Late Latin the past participle of palliare (“to cover with a cloak”)), from pallium (“cloak”).

adjectives.description: palliate (comparative more palliate, superlative most palliate)

examples: [the] most helpful method of its Cure, which yet if palliate and imperfect would onely make way to more fatal Sickness

verbs.description: palliate (third-person singular simple present palliates, present participle palliating, simple past and past participle palliated)

entries.meaning: To relieve the symptoms of; to ameliorate. [from 15th c.]
examples: And if there are some bankers out there who are still embarrassed by the size of their bonuses, then I propose that they palliate their guilt by giving to the Mayor's Fund for London to help deprived children in London.

entries.meaning: To cover or disguise the seriousness of (a mistake, offence etc.) by excuses and apologies. [from 17th c.]
examples: We extenuate not our guilt : whatever we sin , we condemn it as mortal : they palliate wickedness , with the fair pretence of veniality

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To lessen the severity of; to extenuate, moderate, qualify. [17th–18th c.]
examples: If, mindless of palliating circumstances, we are bound to regard the death of the Master-at-arms as the prisoner's deed, then does that deed constitute a capital crime whereof the penalty is a mortal one?
Brown's options for the machinery of Whitehall are constrained, as for all prime ministers, by the need to palliate allies and hug enemies close (John Reid, say).
